options: Admit the child to paediatrics
Advise the mother that whilst slapping is legal it must not leave any marks
Make an anonymous phone call to Social Services reporting your suspicion of child abuse
Write a letter to the GP and health visitor asking for them to follow-up
Contact the local Child Protection Officer
questions:
You are working as a ST1 doctor in the Emergency Department. A mother brings her 8-month-old child in. She says he fell off their bed this morning and wants to get him 'checked over'. On examination the infant appears comfortable but marks possibly consistent with slapping are present on the left side of his torso.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario should clearly raise the possibility of non-accidental injury. The most appropriate action is to admit the child to paediatrics as there he can be formally assessed and appropriate investigations performed (e.g. a skeletal survey). Contacting the local Child Protection Officer would initiate a similar process but would involve an element of delay during which the child may be in danger. Writing a letter to the GP again should hopefully result in the same action taking place but adds unnecessary steps and delay.

Making an anonymous phone call to Social Services is unprofessional and represents a failure to properly discharge your responsibilities. There can be no justification for smacking an 8-month-old and advice which condones this is clearly wrong.

questions:
You are a junior doctor working on a busy Acute Medical Unit. You have been there for over a month and the workload does not seem to be easing up, and you often find yourself working alone on the ward due to rota gaps. You have begun to feel swamped in work, stressed, and have some symptoms of depression.

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes: Stress and burnout is a very real issue for doctors, and you cannot look after your patients to the best of your ability if you are unable to look after yourself. It is important to get some help yourself for your stress. This will usually involve discussing the issue with someone you trust and informing your GP. Continuing on without support could compromise patient care, particularly if you are being left to work alone due to rota gaps. Alerting the relevant local team including your supervisor and Foundation Programme Director is the first step towards resolution. Taking annual leave may help in the short term but will not solve the problem. Contacting the Deanery would be a subsequent step. Discussing with the other FY2 doctors may provide you with some support but ultimately will not change anything for your situation.

title: GMC guidance: doctor's health
body:
The General Medical Council (GMC) makes it explicitly clear that you should not rely on your own judgement of the risk posed by your health to your patients. They state that this should be done by an 'appropriately qualified healthcare professional'. You must seek and follow their advice on any changes to your work necessary. In this case therefore, the only appropriate choice is to consult occupational health.

Risks posed to patients by your own health
  • 'If you know or suspect that you have a serious condition that you could pass on to patients, or if your judgement or performance could be affected by a condition or its treatment, you must consult a suitably qualified colleague.'
  • 'You must follow their advice about any changes to your practice they consider necessary.'
  • 'You must not rely on your own assessment of the risk to patients.'

Good Medical Practice, domain 2, subsections 28-30, GMC 2013
concept: Inform your clinical supervisor in the first instance if you feel that your workload is excessive, and you are suffering from burnout

options: Offer to take on some of their patients to ease their daily workload
Advise them to take sick leave until their issues are resolved
Advise them to discuss the issue with their supervisor
Gather more information about the matter
Report the matter to their supervisor
Suggest to them to seek support via a counsellor
Report your colleague to the General Medical Council (GMC)
Offer to mediate between them and their partner
Contact the patient on their behalf and ask them to drop their complaint
Inform the Training Programme Director (TPD)
questions:
You are working as a GP registrar in a clinic when one of your registrar colleagues confides in you that two patients have recently complained to the practice manager about their care for them. Further, they explain that they are having relationship issues and are struggling with their current workload.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
There are three core themes to this question:

1. The colleague who is struggling with personal issues.

2. Personal issues contributing to them struggling with their workload.

3. Potential compromise of patient safety.

The General Medical Council (GMC) make it clear that a doctor's primary duty is to ensure patient safety. As such, even though it may seem like prying, it is prudent to gather more information (D). In general, it is always important to gather information before providing advice, and in this case, your colleague has brought this up with you themselves so it would seem the natural next step.

If you feel that patient safety is being compromised and the practice manager does not take the steps that you feel are appropriate, it is necessary to escalate the issue. The next point of call would be their supervisor.

This brings us to the next correct answer advising your colleague to raise the issue with their supervisor (C). Their supervisor may be able to take steps to reduce your colleague's workload or alter their working patterns to better support them in this difficult time.

In regards to your colleague's relationship issues, the most appropriate option based on the clinical vignette is to advise them to seek support via a counsellor (F). The vignette does not tell you how familiar you are with this colleague, and as such you should not make any assumptions. This is the more appropriate option than offering to mediate between them and their partner (H) because this assumes a degree of close personal relation to both parties.

Offering to take on some of their patients (A) may help your colleague in the short term but it increases your own workload and may lead to you making mistakes and potentially compromising patient safety. It is not a sustainable option.

It is inappropriate to advise your colleague to take sick leave (B) when they are not sick. If they are truly under such emotional stress that they are feeling too unwell to attend work, then this may be a suitable option but under the caveat that they speak with their supervisor and try to figure out a long-term plan.

You may feel the need to report the matter to their supervisor (E) to help your colleague, but you should allow them the opportunity to do so themselves first.

Reporting your colleague to the GMC (G) based on the limited information provided in the clinical vignette is inappropriate. First, it should be determined whether patient safety has been compromised. If so, the local relevant team should deal with the matter. If you feel the matter has not been dealt with appropriately, inform the GMC.

Asking the patient to drop their complaint (I) is the least appropriate of the options. It involves identifying the patient, and so breaking their right to confidentiality as you are not directly involved in their care. Contacting them to ask them to drop their complaint can be seen as a form of bullying or harassment

The TPD (J) has nothing to do with this matter unless you feel that this issue has arisen out of an issue with the training programme. Nothing in the clinical vignette suggests this is the case.

title: GMC: Raising and acting on concerns about patient safety
body:
The GMC take a firm line on patient safety, in that you must take action if you think patient safety, dignity or comfort is being compromised. This is not always easy, particularly as a student or junior doctor- which is why it is important to be aware of the guidance.

Broad Principles

All doctors have the duty to raise concerns if they believe that patient safety or care is being compromised. This can include when medical students witness poor practice on placement, or family members raise concerns. They must also encourage and support a culture in which staff can raise concerns openly and safely.

Concerns may relate to:
  • The practice of colleagues,
  • The systems in place,
  • Policies and procedures within organisations.

You may be reluctant to report a concern for a number of reasons, particularly if you have not needed to raise concerns in the past. For example:
  • You fear that nothing will be done,
  • You fear that raising your concern may cause problems for colleagues,
  • It could have a negative effect on working relationships or career,
  • It could result in a complaint about you.

While it is natural to have these concerns, keep the following in mind:
  • You have a duty to put patients' interests first and act to protect them. This should override personal and professional loyalties.
  • The law provides legal protection. This is against victimisation or dismissal for individuals who reveal information to raise genuine concerns and expose malpractice in the workplace.
  • You do not need to wait for proof. You can justify raising a concern if you do so honestly, on the basis of reasonable belief and through appropriate channels.

For example, you may believe that a member of staff is intentionally avoiding guidance on hand-washing. When reporting this, you must be clear, honest and objective about the reason for your concern. You should also keep a record of any steps that you have taken to deal with it.

Who to report to

Wherever possible, you should first raise your concern with your manager or an appropriate officer, such as:
  • The consultant in charge of the team,
  • The clinical or medical director,
  • A practice partner.

NB: If your concern is about a partner, it may be appropriate to raise it outside the practice.

If you are a doctor in training, it may be appropriate to raise your concerns with a named person in the deanery. One example could be where a senior clinician has been reported by a number of patients for improper practice, and you would like to seek further advise on what action to take.

You should contact a regulatory body, such as the General Medical Council, in the following circumstances.
  • If you cannot raise the issue with the responsible person or body locally because you believe them to be part of the problem.
  • If you have raised your concern through local channels but are not satisfied that the responsible person or body has taken adequate action.
  • If there is an immediate serious risk to patients, and a regulator or other external body has responsibility to act or intervene.

It is not common to raise concerns publicly, as they can usually be dealt with discretely by the appropriate team. However, you can consider making your concerns public if you:
  • Have done all you can to deal with any concern by raising it within the organisation in which you work or which you have contract with, or with the appropriate external body, and
  • Have good reason to believe that patients are still at risk of harm,
  • Do not breach patient confidentiality.

Acting on Concerns

As a medical student or recently qualified doctor, you may not need to do more than report concerns. However, concerns about patient safety can also come from a number of sources, such as:
  • Patients' complaints,
  • Colleagues' concerns,
  • Critical incident reports,
  • Clinical audit.

If you receive this information, you have a responsibility to act on it promptly and professionally. You can do this by putting the matter right (if possible), investigating and dealing with it locally, or referring serious or repeated incidents to senior management.

If you have a management role or responsibility, you must make sure that:
  • There are systems and policies in place to allow concerns and investigated promptly and fully,
  • You do not try to prevent employees or former employees raising concerns about patient safety,
  • Clinical staff understand their duty to be open and honest about incidents or complaints with both patients and managers,
  • Staff who raise a concern are protected from unfair criticism or action, including any detriment or dismissal.

If you are responsible for investigating incidents or complaints, you must:
  • Tell the person what action has been taken to prevent a recurrence of the problem,
  • Outline the process if they are still not satisfied with the response,
  • Ensure that any investigations or resulting actions are carried out in a way which is consistent with the law.

options: Ensure she knows the risks of not taking them
Accept her wishes
Document the decision in the notes
Write them on her chart in case she changes her mind
Tell her that she needs to take antibiotics
Act in her best interests
Telephone the next of kin to discuss the matter
Use the Mental Capacity Act
questions:
You are a junior doctor in respiratory medicine. You have just been on a ward round with your team and have seen an elderly lady who is suffering from an infective exacerbation of COPD. She is completely compos mentis however is declining antibiotics. She says that they always make her feel worse and refuses to take them. Despite nebulisers she is becoming more breathless and you are worrying that she may deteriorate. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
This lady has capacity to make her own decisions with regards to her treatment therefore you must accept her decision even if you do not agree with it. As a doctor you must still ensure she knows the risk of what could happen if she does not take the treatment, and the whole exchange should be clearly documented for your legal protection.

By writing the antibiotics on her chart you are actually going against her wishes not to have them. If she changes her mind you can easily return to write them on. It is likely that if a medicine is written on a treatment chart then they will be given to the patient. This patient does have a choice not to take antibiotics and telling her that she has no choice would be a lie. You do not act in someone's best interest if they have capacity to make a decision. In a situation where a person has capacity to make a decision, speaking with the next of kin is also inappropriate. You would only use the Mental Capacity Act in a person lacking capacity.

title: Mental Capacity Act
body:
The Mental Capacity Act of 2005 came into force in 2007. It applies to adults over the age of 16 and sets out who can take decisions if a patient becomes incapacitated (e.g. following a stroke). Mental capacity includes the ability to make decisions affecting daily life, healthcare and financial issues.

The Act contains 5 key principles:
  • A person must be assumed to have capacity unless it is established that he lacks capacity
  • A person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision unless all practicable steps to help him to do so have been taken without success
  • A person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision merely because he makes an unwise decision
  • An act done, or decision made, under this Act for or on behalf of a person who lacks capacity must be done, or made, in his best interests
  • Before the act is done, or the decision is made, regard must be had to whether the purpose for which it is needed can be as effectively achieved in a way that is less restrictive of the person's rights and freedom of action

Assessment of capacity

The Act sets out a clear test for assessing whether a person lacks capacity. It is a 'decision-specific' and 'time-specific' test. An adult can only be considered unable to make a particular decision if:

1. He or she has an 'impairment of, or disturbance in, the functioning of the mind or
brain' whether permanent or temporary AND

2. He or she is unable to undertake any of the following
  • a. understand the information relevant to the decision
  • b. retain that information
  • c. use or weigh that information as part of the process of making the decision
  • d. communicate the decision made by talking, sign language or other means

No individual can be labelled 'incapable' simply as a result of a particular medical condition. Section 2 of the Act makes it clear that a lack of capacity cannot be assumed by a person's age, appearance, or any condition or aspect of a person's behaviour

Best interests

The following should be considered when assessing what is in someone's best interests:
  • 1. Whether the person is likely to regain capacity and can the decision wait.
  • 2. How to encourage and optimise the participation of the person in the decision.
  • 3. The past and present wishes, feelings, beliefs, values of the person and any other relevant factors
  • 4. Views of other relevant people

Lasting Powers of Attorney (LPAs)

The Act allows a person to appoint an attorney to act on their behalf if they should lose capacity in the future, replacing the current Enduring Power of Attorney (EPA). In addition to property and financial affairs the Act also allows people to empower an attorney make health and welfare decisions. The attorney only has the authority to make decisions about life-sustaining treatment if the LPA specifies that. Before it can be used an LPA must be registered with the Office of the Public Guardian

Advance decisions

Advance decisions can be drawn up by anybody with capacity to specify treatments they would not want if they lost capacity. They may be made verbally unless they specify refusing life-sustaining treatment (e.g. Ventilation) in which case they need to be written, signed and witnessed to be valid. Advance decisions cannot demand treatment

options: Ask the district nurses for more details on the protocols they work to
Tell the district nurse that she must fit the compression stockings as the consultant has overall responsibility for the patient
Phone the consultant to discuss the situation
Offer to fit the compression stockings yourself
Make a formal complaint to the Nursing and Midwifery Council and fit the compression stockings yourself
questions:
You are a GP registrar. You receive a letter from the local vascular consultant regarding one of your patients with a chronic leg ulcer. It asks for her to have compression stockings fitted. A referral is therefore made to the district nurses. A few days later you get a phone call from the senior district nurse who says she is not happy to fit compression stockings on this particular patient due to low ABPI readings. On reviewing the consultant letter you see that they are aware of the low ABPI readings. You phone the district nurses to discuss this but they say that due to their protocol they are unwilling to fit them.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
In this scenario you have found yourself in the middle of a disagreement between other healthcare colleagues. The first step is to ask the district nurses for more information on their protocols. This may also help clear up any misunderstandings or mistakes in your referral letter.

The next best step is to inform the vascular consultant. He/she will otherwise presume that their management plan is being implemented. They may also offer to speak to the district nurses themselves to try and resolve the situation.

It is unlikely that you are skilled in fitting compression stockings so this is a poor option. Health professionals should act according to their own guidelines and cannot be compelled to take particular actions. There are no grounds to make a complaint here.

options: Decline the gift explaining the professional rules that govern doctors
Thank him for the kind gesture but decline the gift adding that if he wishes to thank you, a card will be more than enough
Accept the gift + record it in the practice register of gifts
Ask for the cash equivalent instead and put it towards your child's education
Accept the gift + write a letter of thanks
questions:
A patient that you have known for the past 10 months comes to see you. Last year you organised a fast-track referral after he presented with rectal bleeding. He was eventually diagnosed with rectal carcinoma and had curative surgery. As a result he is extremely grateful for your early referral and states that he wants to thank you with the gift of a 50 inch LED TV for your new home.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
A 50 inch LED TV represents a substantial gift with a probable value of greater than £400. The GMC have the following to say on gifts:

'You must not encourage patients to give, lend or bequeath money or gifts that will directly or indirectly benefit you.'

When offered a gift of such substantial value it is therefore important to apply judgement. One of the important considerations is the future impact on your relationship with the patient. We are all human and it is very difficult for anyone to say that receiving such a gift would not influence their future relationship with the patient.

The best option is therefore to politely decline the gift. Suggesting that the patient gives you a card allows a chance for the patient to express their thanks. This is a better option than just explaining the GMC rules.

If you do accept the gift it is important that you register the gift so that it is out in the open. Asking for the cash equivalent is a very poor option as it is essentially encouraging a cash gift to yourself.

options: Thank James and register the gift with the hospital
Politely leave as James is trying to bribe you
Politely explain that you are unable to discuss his father's condition with him unless Mr Smith consents to his information being shared
Decline the money and explain that you are unable to accept money in exchange for information
Listen to his concerns
Thank James and tell him to donate the money to a cancer charity instead
Thank James and take the cash. Tell him not to inform anyone of this and tell him everything about his father

questions:
You are a F2 working on the Gastro ward. You have been caring for Mr Smith, a 78-year-old with gastric cancer, for the last 3 weeks. His son James approaches you, asking to speak with you. You take him to the family room to discuss his concerns where he offers you £500 in cash to discuss his father's condition with him as his father is refusing to tell him what is wrong.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The correct options are 3, 4 and 5. Patients have a right to confidentiality. It is Mr Smith's choice not to inform his family of his condition and you must respect this as a healthcare professional. However, this does not mean that you do not show compassion towards the son who may be feeling frustrated and at a loss. It is always good to listen to their concerns (option 1). You should decline the money and explain that you cannot give information in exchange for money (option 4). It is then important that you explain to the patient why you cannot share information- you need the patient's consent to do this (option 5).

All the other options break confidentiality, are unethical or accept a bribe. Telling James to donate the money to a charity may be putting undue pressure on him as he may now feel obliged to give the money.

The main theme in this question is confidentiality. For more information on confidentiality, see the GMC guidelines here: http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethicalguidance/confidentiality.asp

The main theme in this question is confidentiality. For more information on confidentiality, see the GMC guidelines here: http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethicalguidance/confidentiality.asp

questions:
You are a ST3 working in General Practice. During a routine consultation, a 18-year-old man confides to you that he has been buying anabolic steroids over the Internet for bodybuilding purposes.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
Anabolic steroids are a Class C drug. It is illegal to distribute but not illegal to possess for personal use.
There are many side effects and risks with taking anabolic steroids, particularly with unregulated substances purchased over the Internet.

The correct options here are 2 (offer blood tests), 4 (advise stopping), 5 (inform about risks).

  • We can immediately rule out options 3 (reporting to police), 6 (telling family), and 7 (informing authorities), as these involve breaching the patient's right to confidentiality.
  • Option 8 is also inappropriate. Even though you are not telling his workplace directly that he is using steroids, you are breaching confidentiality by indirectly letting them know that he has come to see you, and that there may be cause for concern about his behaviour.
  • Option 1 (advising a patient on the best method to illegally obtain controlled drugs) is clearly unprofessional!

Patient-doctor confidentiality can only be broken in extreme situations, and a patient using illicit drugs does not justify this, unless he is putting himself or others at risk of serious harm.

You may personally strongly disagree with the patient's decision to take recreational drugs. However this must not result in personal bias in how you treat the patient. You should offer blood tests if they are clinically appropriate.

GMC 'Good Medical Practice':
- You must not disclose personal information to a third party such as a solicitor, police officer or officer of a court without the patients express consent, unless it is required by law or can be justified in the public interest.
(Disclosing in the public interest is defined as 'to protect individuals or society from risks of serious harm, such as serious communicable diseases or serious crime'.)

- The investigations or treatment you provide or arrange must be based on the assessment you and your patient make of their needs and priorities, and on your clinical judgement about the likely effectiveness of the treatment options. You must not refuse or delay treatment because you believe that a patients actions or lifestyle have contributed to their condition.

options: See the patient as scheduled but then decline any further consultations
Change the appointment to a telephone call
Ask reception to cancel the appointment and book them into the next routine appointment slot
Ask reception to cancel the appointment and book them into tomorrows on-call list
Discuss your concerns with your GP supervisor
Call the patient and tell them you no longer feel safe to provide care for them
Offer to see the patient in a joint clinic with another GP
Ask your colleagues to see if anyone can swap their appointments after explaining your reasoning
Find out who booked the appointment and make a complaint about them to the practice manager
Inform the practice manager of the booking and ask for your concerns to be relayed to the booking team
questions:
You are a doctor working in a GP rotation. On checking your clinic list for the following day you can see a patient booked in who, on their last appointment with you, became verbally aggressive and punched the clinic room wall after you declined to prescribe them diazepam. You and your GP supervisor agreed that you should end your professional relationship with the patient. This has been documented on the booking system and communicated to the patient. The patient also received a written notice of this as well as a warning from the practice. There are no remaining routine appointments tomorrow and you do not know why they have requested the appointment.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The General Medical Council (GMC) has issued clear guidance on terminating a professional relationship with a patient. Given your previous consultation which culminated in verbally and physically aggressive behaviours from the patient, they received written notice that you would not be involved in their future care. This scenario tests your ability to deal with this stressful situation calmly whilst ensuring your well-being is being looked after, as well as ensuring the patient is seen.

As such discussing your concerns with your GP supervisor (E) is a correct response. This will be helpful not only to discuss your concerns and potential emotional response following your last encounter, but they may also be able to see the patient or provide a suitable alternative.

Ask your colleagues to see if anyone can swap their appointments after explaining your reasoning (H) would also be a proactive response to this situation, demonstrating your ability to solve the situation. The colleague should be aware of the challenges of your previous consultation in this instance.

Inform the practice manager of the booking and ask for your concerns to be relayed to the booking team (J) is also appropriate. The practice has a record stating you should not be involved in the patient's care and so this should be fed back to the booking team to avoid similar situations happening again.

See the patient as scheduled but then decline any further consultations (A) is inappropriate as you have already terminated your relationship with the patient. This would have ramifications on your well-being and is potentially unsafe given their previous actions.

Change the appointment to a telephone call (B) still involves you contacting the patient which would be inappropriate given you have ended your professional relationship with the patient.

Ask reception to cancel the appointment and book them into the next routine appointment slot (C) is inappropriate as you do not know why the patient has booked the appointment and their issue may not be able to wait until the next available appointment.

Ask reception to cancel the appointment and book them into tomorrow's on-call list (D) is again inappropriate without further information. Any on-calls, be that in GP or hospital settings, can be busy so booking a routine clinic appointment into an on-call slot would not be the best course of action unless clinically required.

Call the patient and tell them you no longer feel safe to provide care for them (F) would be incorrect as this could escalate the situation following your previous consultation.

Offer to see the patient in a joint clinic with another GP (G) would likewise be inappropriate as you should not have any involvement with the patient after ending your professional relationship with them.

Find out who booked the appointment and make a complaint about them to the practice manager (I) would be less appropriate than the other options listed. Though you would rightly be able to question the issue that the appointment was booked in the first place, complaining about a colleague without further information could make the situation worse.

title: GMC: Ending your professional relationship with a patient
body:
The GMC guidelines contain information on ending your professional relationship with a patient. They state that;

You must only end a professional relationship with a patient when the breakdown of trust means you cannot provide good clinical care. This includes the patient being violent, threatening you or being abusive or the patient having stolen from you or the premises. It also includes the patient persistently acted inconsiderately or unreasonably or if they have made a sexual advance to you.

You should not end a relationship due to a complaint or due to resource implications.

Before you end the relationship you must warn the patient you are considering ending it and do what you can to restore the relationship. If this fails you must explore alternatives to ending it and discuss the situation with an experienced colleague or your employer.

When you end a relationship you must be satisfied that your reason is fair and does not discriminate. Then make sure the patient is told this is happening, and why. If practical do this in writing.

options: Agree to do the procedure and carry it out
Seek consent from the patient to ensure they are happy for you to conduct the procedure, despite not having done one before, and then do the drain if they are happy for you to do so
Inform your consultant that you have never done this procedure before and would like to observe one
Agree to do the procedure and ask a fellow ST1 friend who has done the procedure to do it on your behalf
Inform your consultant that you have never done this procedure before
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on the acute medical ward. Your consultant asks you to insert an ascitic drain. You have never done this procedure before, nor observed one. You have, however, attended teaching classes and practiced the correct technique on models.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question is something that may come up in clinical practice, with everybody having had different experiences of procedures throughout training. The main issue in this question is preserving patient safety.

Informing your consultant that you have never done this procedure before and then requesting to view the procedure being carried out (3) is the best answer. This is because you do not endanger patients by admitting that you have never done an ascitic drain before. Furthermore, you are showing your consultant the desire to learn by requesting to view somebody who is more experienced conduct one. This is better than option 5 as you are showing that willingness to learn how to do an ascitic drain.

Agreeing to do the procedure and asking a fellow foundation doctor to do the procedure for you is dishonest. You would be taking credit for something that you have not done, allowing your consultant to think that you are competent in a skill that you are not, and lying that it is you that has undertaken the procedure. However, this ranks higher than options 2 and 1 as these two options endanger patient safety.

Option 2 might at first glance appear a good option. Requesting consent from a patient when you would like to carry out a procedure that you have never done before should be done, however, by carrying out the ascitic drain yourself you are putting this patient's safety at risk. This is a better option than option 1 however, as in this response you are still placing patient safety at risk but have also not considered the patient's autonomy.
